I found comprehensive information about the Hawthorne Studies and their connection to social engineering, industrial psychology, and workplace behavior. Here's what the search revealed:

## The Hawthorne Studies Overview

The Hawthorne Studies were conducted at Western Electric's Hawthorne Plant in Cicero during the 1920s and 30s, fundamentally influencing management theories.(no content)The studies were conducted by Elton Mayo and his colleagues in the 1920s and 1930s and revolutionized our understanding of workplace dynamics and organizational behavior.

## Research Team and Methodology

The scientists included in the research team were Elton Mayo (Psychologist), Roethlisberger and Whilehead (Sociologists), and William Dickson (company representative).(no content)Elton Mayo and his team designed the studies to investigate the effects of physical and social conditions on worker productivity at the Western Electric Hawthorne Works in Chicago, encompassing several experiments to determine how changes in work conditions, such as lighting, rest breaks, and work hours, affected employee performance.

## Key Experiments and Findings

### The Illumination Studies (1924-1927)
Between 1924 and 1927, a team of researchers from Harvard Business School conducted experiments at Hawthorne Works aimed at identifying whether there was an effect of illumination on the productivity of their workers, with their hypothesis being that well-lit rooms would increase productivity.(no content)Worker productivity improved when the lights were dimmed again and when everything had been returned to the way it was before the experiment began, productivity at the factory was at its highest level and absenteeism had plummeted.

### The Relay Assembly Test Room (1927-1932)
One experiment involved two women who were chosen as test subjects and were then asked to choose four other workers to join the test group, and together, the women worked assembling telephone relays in a separate room over the course of five years (1927–1932).(no content)Analysis found that "Regardless of the conditions, whether there were more or fewer rest periods, longer or shorter workdays…the women worked harder and more efficiently."

## The Discovery of Social and Psychological Factors

Mayo found that workers were more responsive to social factors—such as their manager and coworkers—than the factors (lighting, etc.) the researchers set out to investigate, discovering that workers were highly responsive to additional attention from their managers and the feeling that their managers actually cared about and were interested in their work.(no content)The studies highlighted the importance of psychological and social factors in workplace productivity, such as employee attention and group dynamics, leading to a more human-centric approach in management practices.

## The "Hawthorne Effect"

In 1958, Henry A. Landsberger coined the term 'Hawthorne effect' while evaluating a series of studies at the plant.(no content)The Hawthorne effect is a type of human behavior reactivity in which individuals modify an aspect of their behavior in response to their awareness of being observed.

## Ethical Considerations and Manipulation

The experiment involved close observation and manipulation of work conditions, raising questions about the potential stress or discomfort experienced by workers and ethical considerations related to the potential psychological impact on participants.(no content)Modern ethical standards prioritize minimizing harm and ensuring the welfare of research participants, requiring informed consent, thorough debriefing, and ensuring that any induced behaviors do not have adverse long-term effects, with the ethical considerations surrounding the Hawthorne Studies contributing to the development of stricter guidelines to protect participants.

## Impact on Industrial Psychology and Management

The Hawthorne studies are credited with focusing managerial strategy on the socio-psychological aspects of human behavior in organizations.(no content)The experiments brought to light ideas concerning motivational influences, job satisfaction, resistance to change, group norms, worker participation, and effective leadership, which were groundbreaking concepts in the 1930s.

The studies marked a significant shift from earlier approaches like Frederick Taylor's work, which took a "man as machine" view and focused on ways of improving individual performance, while Hawthorne set the individual in a social context, arguing that employees' performance is influenced by work surroundings and coworkers as much as by employee ability and skill.
